# How a Book is Created? Episode 1 - The Idea

Have you ever wondered how a book is created?

## The Idea and Its Processing

Obvious? Sure. If you don't know what to write about, you don't write  well, you can, of course... writing when you think you know how but don't even know what you want to say is called graphomania.

I thought I might have it for a while, but fortunately I went with my text for beta-reader diagnostics to a specialist. I got a certificate of no graphomania symptoms and some encouragement.

## Different Approaches to the Idea

An idea is needed so that the words we set in motion have something to do. But that's where the similarities between different authors' approaches probably end.

Some authors prefer to tell stories and evoke emotions, others care most about making the reader think. There are also those who want to show some historical background or important events.

## My Idea

When I thought about what later became the book "Mirrors We Don't Have", I wanted to address the topic of loneliness, which is an increasingly serious social problem, arising from many different issues.

Technology deepens this problem, and is often its cause, while pretending it can be its cure. The title of this book was quite obvious once I told myself what I wanted to tell.

## Processing the Idea

The author must digest their idea, feel this story, even if they don't yet know (and often don't) exactly how it will unfold. An idea doesn't always mean knowing everything from beginning to end.

A novel is created in the process of creation, however strange that sounds. I don't know exactly where my characters will take me, it only becomes clear once I set them in motion.

Writing "Mirrors" I knew what the characters would be like and what should result from telling about them, but I didn't know the ending. When I wrote "The Stick and the Carrot" I knew what the main events would be and what the ending would be. In other projects I also have the main plot line worked out, but the novel is created by its characters.
